abstract: Drought, famine and the anti-Western policies of the Shabab, a militant faction, hinder efforts to feed and clothe hundreds of thousands of refugees, many of them children.
snippet: Drought, famine and the anti-Western policies of the Shabab, a militant faction, hinder efforts to feed and clothe hundreds of thousands of refugees, many of them children.
lead_paragraph: BENADIR HOSPITAL is a chunky block of a building in downtown Mogadishu, built in the 1970s by the Chinese. It has cracked windows, ceiling fans that don’t turn and long, ghostly hallways that stink of human excrement and diesel fuel — all that the nurses have to wash the floors. Each morning, legions of starving people trudge in, the victims of Somalia’s spreading famine. Many have journeyed from hundreds of miles away. They spent every last dollar and every last calorie to make it here, and when they arrive, they simply collapse on the floor. Benadir’s few doctors and nurses are all volunteers and all exhausted, and many wear tattered, bloodied smocks. The minute I walked in, I had a bad feeling I would find what I was looking for.

headline.main: Somalia’s Agony Tests Limits of Aid

abstract: Excess stock market volatility ­ — price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks — has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and during the financial crisis and recession of 2008 and 2009. The charts show the difference between the amount the Standard & Poor’s 500 moved over each 13-week period and the total of the daily changes, without regard to whether the daily move was up or down, and expresses the amount as a percentage of the index value at the beginning of each 13-week period. In a market that went up every day, or down every day, over a 13-week period, the figure would be zero. Highlighted areas show recessions.

abstract: The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways said it reached an agreement with Lufthansa of Germany to acquire its British Midland International unit.
snippet: The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways said it reached an agreement with Lufthansa of Germany to acquire its British Midland International unit.
lead_paragraph: The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia, said on Friday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with Lufthansa of Germany to acquire its British Midland International unit. Details of the transaction, including a binding purchase agreement, were still being negotiated, I.A.G. said. The sale would also be subject to the completion of due diligence and clearance from competition regulators. News of the prospective takeover came as I.A.G. announced a 31 percent drop in third-quarter operating profit to 363 million euros, from 528 million euros a year earlier. The group blamed rising fuel prices and weaker travel demand from leisure passengers. Lufthansa had sought for several months to sell British Midland, which analysts have valued at 300 million to 400 million euros, or $414.5 million to $552.6 million.

headline.main: Lufthansa in Preliminary Deal to Sell a British Unit
headline.print_headline: Lufthansa in Preliminary Deal to Sell a British Unit

snippet: When the verdict in Conrad Murray trial arrived, networks broke in for live coverage, cable networks hit the hyper-drive button and pundits played Ping-Pong with the verdict deep into the night. But audiences seem to shrug.
lead_paragraph: In a bit of anticlimax, Dr. Conrad Murray was found guilty late in the day on Monday of involuntary manslaughter two-and-a-half years after the death of Michael Jackson. Networks broke in for live coverage, cable networks hit the hyperdrive button and pundits played Ping-Pong with the verdict deep into the night, but audiences seem to shrug. Ratings on the verdict coverage are not known yet, but The Hollywood Reporter said during the trial that the case failed to ignite audience interest on HLN, CNN’s sibling networked that had promised wall-to-wall coverage.

headline.main: Jackson Doctor Trial Fails to Ignite Audience Interest

abstract: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia.
snippet: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia.
lead_paragraph: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia, the latest move in a global expansion by Sinopec, China’s largest oil refiner. Under the terms of the deal, the state-owned Sinopec will invest $4.8 billion for a 30 percent stake in Petrogal Brasil, a subsidiary of Galp Energia. The Chinese company will make lend an additional $390 million to the Brazilian business. Galp Energia will retain the remaining 70 percent of Petrogal Brasil. The deal values the company’s Brazilian assets at $12.5 billion. China’s energy companies have spent billions of dollars in recent years to gain access to new energy resources. In October, Sinopec agreed to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion. The Chinese company also paid $7.1 billion last year for a 40 percent stake in the Brazilian assets of the Spanish energy firm Repsol YPF.

headline.main: Sinopec Buys Stake in Portuguese Energy Company
headline.print_headline: Sinopec Buys Stake in Portuguese Energy Company

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Peabody Energy said on Wednesday that it had acquired more than 90 percent of Macarthur Coal of Australia. The announcement allows Peabody, an American coal company, to require Macarthur’s remaining shareholders, including the South Korean steel maker Posco, to sell their stakes.

headline.main: Peabody Energy Wins Full Control of Macarthur Coal

abstract: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new “Early Show” lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store.
snippet: Reporters are arrested in Zuccotti Park, CBS presents its new “Early Show” lineup and Google is expected to announce its own online music-download store.
lead_paragraph: The day after the nighttime raid that cleared protesters from Zuccotti Park, the New York Police Department was criticized by local politicians and news organizations for its treatment of reporters and the restrictions it placed on how they do their work. The Associated Press reported that at least half a dozen reporters were arrested in and around the park, home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, including a reporter and photographer from the agency. Michael Oreskes, senior managing editor for The A.P., said: “Journalists should not be restricted from access to news events or detained for attempting to do their jobs. We were unhappy that two of our staff members were swept up in the police operation, but we appreciate the N.Y.P.D.’s decision to release them.”

headline.main: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 16

abstract: For small-business owners who take venture capital, it can feel like a deal with the devil.
snippet: For small-business owners who take venture capital, it can feel like a deal with the devil.
lead_paragraph: On the last day of the fourth quarter in 2008, BC Krishna was trying to clinch a deal with a large, name-brand company. The transaction would have put his small start-up, Memento, a fraud-detection company, on the map. When the deal fell through, Mr. Krishna worried about how his venture capitalist investors would react — especially because it meant that Memento was going to fall short of its performance targets.

headline.main: Entrepreneurs Looking For Capital Investment Seek Kindred Spirits
headline.print_headline: Entrepreneurs Looking For Capital Investment Seek Kindred Spirits

abstract: A founder who takes venture capital gets the opportunity to grow but also risks losing control of the company. Can an empathetic ear help?
snippet: A founder who takes venture capital gets the opportunity to grow but also risks losing control of the company. Can an empathetic ear help?
lead_paragraph: Most small-business owners never seek venture capital, writes Pamela Ryckman in an article we’ve just published, but for those who do, it can feel like a deal with the devil. Venture-backed companies are expected to grow quickly, and their boards can impose rigorous controls, audits and metrics. A founder who takes venture capital gets the opportunity to grow but also risks losing control of the company. One way entrepreneurs mitigate the tension in the relationship is to work with venture capitalists who may have more patience during the company-building process — because they have been through it themselves.

headline.main: Do Former Entrepreneurs Make Better Venture Capitalists?

abstract: Regulators are replacing an opaque system prone to failure with a huge, Rube Goldberg-like system that may reduce global financial risk. Or it may not. Nobody knows.
snippet: Regulators are replacing an opaque system prone to failure with a huge, Rube Goldberg-like system that may reduce global financial risk. Or it may not. Nobody knows.
lead_paragraph: When the architects of the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul flinched from the most effective solution — breaking up the banks so that none would be too big to drag down the financial system — they forced regulators of the derivatives market into a cumbersome and potentially dangerous workaround.

headline.main: Reform Adds More Twists to a Convoluted Derivatives World

abstract: How should TastingRoom.com woo investors who are still shell-shocked from the misadventures of other online wine retailers?
snippet: How should TastingRoom.com woo investors who are still shell-shocked from the misadventures of other online wine retailers?
lead_paragraph: Using a technology that sounds more NASA than Napa, TastingRoom.com “reformats” wines from their original retail packaging into 50- and 100-milliliter, single-serving bottles. Technicians re-pour some 1,000 varieties of wine inside an oxygen- and particle-free Plexiglas clean room, which is 40 feet long and protected from contamination by a pair of airlocks, similar to the entry and exit vestibules on a spacecraft. Tiny bottles mean consumers can sample high-quality individual wines without committing to buy a traditional 750-milliliter bottle of each one.

headline.main: Bringing the Tasting Room to the Living Room

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Fall TV Ratings Game has come and gone. Times readers who thought they knew better than the network executives which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1 and predicted which shows would be cancelled first. And who can argue with them?

abstract: Steven Chu, the energy secretary, said the company’s later bankruptcy was “extremely unfortunate,” but he saw no need to apologize.

abstract: A shipbuilding company is hiring in Alabama, and the face of the company is a welder, Betty Jo Fain, who was homeless and struggling with addictions only four years ago.

lead_paragraph: When Betty Jo Fain was a homeless woman struggling with a drug and alcohol problem, the last thing she imagined was being the face for an advertising campaign promoting jobs at a naval shipbuilding company. On Thursday, her face was that face for Austal USA, the shipbuilding company where she works as a welder.

headline.main: From Homelessness to an Ad Campaign, With Employment Along the Way

abstract: Last year, more than one in 10 families received food stamps, but the share was highest in Oregon, where nearly one in five families did so, according to a new Census Bureau report.
snippet: Last year, more than one in 10 families received food stamps, but the share was highest in Oregon, where nearly one in five families did so, according to a new Census Bureau report.
lead_paragraph: Casey Mulligan noted Wednesday on Economix that United States spending on food stamps had skyrocketed since the recession began. A new Census Bureau report provides a look at just how big the program has become. Last year, more than one in 10 families received food stamps, with some states having significantly higher participation rates. In Oregon, the share was nearly one in five.

headline.main: United States of Hunger

abstract: The Supreme Court is to hear oral arguments in the case of Prometheus Laboratories, which believes it owns a method for interpreting how patients react to a drug.
snippet: The Supreme Court is to hear oral arguments in the case of Prometheus Laboratories, which believes it owns a method for interpreting how patients react to a drug.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court has a chance to reverse the mission creep in patent law. The system is supposed to reward inventors but not stifle innovation. Fuzzy and overly broad concepts like thought processes generally are not protected. Yet one company, Prometheus Laboratories, reckons it owns a method for interpreting how patients react to a drug.

headline.main: Patent Case Will Test Court
headline.print_headline: Making Sense Of Patent Law

abstract: The special Congressional committee is unlikely to strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday, leaving investors, business leaders and consumers bracing for another blow to a fragile recovery.
snippet: The special Congressional committee is unlikely to strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday, leaving investors, business leaders and consumers bracing for another blow to a fragile recovery.
lead_paragraph: Expectations that the special Congressional committee will strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday’s deadline could not be much lower. The committee’s own members have played down the odds. Stock prices may already reflect the likelihood of a punt. And one of the major ratings agencies has said the lack of an agreement, by itself, will not result in a downgrade of government debt.

headline.main: Low Expectations, and Trepidation, Over Meeting a Debt Deadline

lead_paragraph: 8:55 a.m. | Updated  The business of politics is good business for TV, CBS’s chief executive, Leslie Moonves, said Thursday during a question-and-answer session at a Hollywood Radio and Television Society luncheon at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, The Los Angeles Times reported. With its range of TV and radio stations, CBS could collect as much as $250 million of the estimated $2.4 billion that is expected to be generated by political campaigns across the country, The Times wrote. Such sums have only grown larger because of a 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions.

abstract: Germany’s strong recovery from the recession helped buoy much of Europe, but now its growth is slowing as that of many of its neighbors has come to a standstill.
snippet: Germany’s strong recovery from the recession helped buoy much of Europe, but now its growth is slowing as that of many of its neighbors has come to a standstill.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the world economy hit bottom in early 2009, Germany has been the engine of growth in Europe. No major industrial economy — in or out of Europe — has grown as rapidly. But new figures released this week indicated that the German economy was growing at its slowest rate since the recovery began, and that much of Europe was no longer growing at all.

headline.main: In Europe, Even a Powerhouse Is Losing Steam

lead_paragraph: New York remains envious of the wealth and success of Silicon Valley. It has tried to duplicate it and failed. But it is trying again, reports Gina Bellafante, the Big City columnist at the New York Times. Positioning New York for 21st-century global supremacy has been a preoccupation of the Bloomberg administration, she write, and one central to the mayor’s vision of greatly expanding the technology sector by ratcheting up elite science education.

headline.main: Re-engineering New York: More Than a Sci-Fi Dream?

abstract: With a $6 million financing deal and plans to double its workforce, Yipit, a company that aggregates and filters daily deals for subscribers, exemplifies the expanding promise of New York’s tech scene.
snippet: With a $6 million financing deal and plans to double its workforce, Yipit, a company that aggregates and filters daily deals for subscribers, exemplifies the expanding promise of New York’s tech scene.
lead_paragraph: Yipit, which aggregates and filters daily deals from companies like Groupon and Living Social, is an example of the high-tech start-up that is altering the employment picture in New York. Alan Feuer, of the New York Times, reports that high-tech employment in New York is shooting up by 30 percent in the last five years, at a time when overall private-sector employment has decreased. New York recently surpassed Boston in the amount of venture capital invested in Internet start-ups, and lags behind only San Francisco.

headline.main: Yipit, on the Move, in a Thriving Tech Sector

lead_paragraph: Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an  oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday. The fines reflect the government’s anger over Chevron’s handling of the spill. Chevron may also face additional fines and legal penalties, officials said. Haroldo Lima, head of the National Petroleum Agency, said the spill could complicate Chevron’s hopes of gaining access to new offshore exploration areas. Federal investigators said Chevron employees might also face prison terms. Chevron said in a statement that it had not yet received official notice of any fines and would respond if it did.

headline.main: Brazil: Chevron Faces Fines of $83 Million in Oil Spill

abstract: The Tribune Company will pay a settlement to Randy Michaels, Ron Paul got more airtime at Tuesday night’s debate and more on the planned Facebook phone.
snippet: The Tribune Company will pay a settlement to Randy Michaels, Ron Paul got more airtime at Tuesday night’s debate and more on the planned Facebook phone.
lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company, which is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to pay its former chief executive, Randy Michaels, $675,000 in a settlement stemming from his abrupt resignation from the company last year, The Chicago Tribune reported. The company will also cover $50,000 in Mr. Michaels’s legal fees. Mr. Michaels resigned under pressure, following reporting in The New York Times that detailed numerous instances of outlandish, often sexual behavior by Mr. Michaels and other top executives. The Tribune reported that he had demanded $900,000, the pro-rated portion of his 2010 management bonus, arguing that he “was effectively ‘terminated without cause,’ which would trigger the payment under terms of the bonus plan.” The payment needs to be approved by a bankruptcy court judge.In Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate on CNN, which was devoted to national security issues, The Caucus live blog took note of the higher profile of Representative Ron Paul, the libertarian from Texas, who often can be hard to spot at these seemingly weekly encounters. As Trip Gabriel wrote for The Caucus, Mr. Paul’s campaign “had claimed after the last debate hosted by CBS News that he got only 90 seconds of air time,” but Tuesday night he played a more central role, serving as a dramatic foil to his rivals. He clashed with Newt Gingrich over the the Patriot Act, and Rick Santorum over profiling of travelers, including Muslims.

headline.main: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 23

abstract: Panasonic said on Friday that it would invest 45 billion yen ($582 million) to build a plant for solar cells and modules in Malaysia in a move to increase its share of the global market.
snippet: Panasonic said on Friday that it would invest 45 billion yen ($582 million) to build a plant for solar cells and modules in Malaysia in a move to increase its share of the global market.
lead_paragraph: Panasonic said on Friday that it would invest 45 billion yen ($582 million) to build a plant for solar cells and modules in Malaysia in a move to increase its share of the global market. The factory will also produce wafers and have a production capacity of 300 megawatts a year, the company said. Panasonic, based in Osaka, Japan, intends to sell modules worth 1.6 gigawatts worldwide in the year ending March 2016, Masato Ito, an executive officer, said at a news conference. The company’s previous target was 1.5 gigawatts. The company picked Malaysia for the new plant to hedge risks of a strong yen and for its reliable infrastructure for power and water, Tetsuhiro Maeda, a senior vice president of Sanyo, a unit of Panasonic, said at the conference. Production will begin in December 2012 and the plant, which will be built in the Kulim Hi-Tech Park in Kedah, in northern Malaysia, will employ about 1,500 people.

headline.main: Panasonic Plans a Plant for Solar Equipment
headline.print_headline: Panasonic Plans a Plant For Solar Equipment

abstract: Irish Life and Permanent, the mortgage lender controlled by Irish taxpayers, said it had suspended efforts to sell its life assurance unit after bids were too low.
snippet: Irish Life and Permanent, the mortgage lender controlled by Irish taxpayers, said it had suspended efforts to sell its life assurance unit after bids were too low.
lead_paragraph: Irish Life and Permanent, the mortgage lender controlled by Irish taxpayers, said it had suspended efforts to sell its life assurance unit after bids were too low. The lender halted the sale process amid “very challenging” market conditions, Eoin Dorgan, a spokesman for the Irish Department of Finance, said in a statement. The Irish government plans to split insurance operations from the unprofitable bank unit. Taxpayers injected 2.7 billion euros into the company in July as part of the country’s 62 billion euro bailout of its banking system. The government owns 99.5 percent of the firm.

headline.main: Irish Life Suspends an Effort to Sell a Unit
headline.print_headline: Irish Life Suspends An Effort To Sell a Unit

abstract: The son of Italian immigrants, Mr. Paulucci founded Chun King, Jeno’s and Michelina’s.
snippet: The son of Italian immigrants, Mr. Paulucci founded Chun King, Jeno’s and Michelina’s.
lead_paragraph: First it was Chun King, the canned Chinese food that became a mainstay in American cupboards in the postwar decades. Then it was the pizza roll, a hybrid of Italian and Chinese fast food that acquired similar status in the kitchen freezer. Jeno Paulucci, a food magnate, had a hand in both of those contributions to the American diet, founding the companies that produced them. He died at 93 on Thursday at his home in Duluth, Minn.

abstract: Herman Cain confronts new allegations during an appearance on CNN, Facebook plans an initial public offering and the movie award season kicks off in New York.

lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, whose campaign had already been stung by accusations of sexual harassment, was confronted with allegations on Monday that he carried on a 13-year affair with an Atlanta businesswoman. Because the story broke while Mr. Cain was live on CNN’s “The Situation Room,” he responded to the allegations by the woman, Ginger White, before they had actually aired on the Fox affiliate in Atlanta, WAGA-TV. According to The Huffington Post, the allegations “didn’t come up during Cain’s first segment with anchor Wolf Blitzer. That’s because Blitzer didn’t know about them either when the two men sat down.” During that first segment of three, CNN producers began to see posts to Twitter that mentioned the coming WAGA story. “While seated during a commercial break, Blitzer then asked Cain about the Atlanta report and the candidate acknowledged that his campaign had been contacted about it and would be willing to discuss it on air,” Michael Calderone of The Huffington Post reported. [Huffington Post]

lead_paragraph: A licensing panel at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has turned down the state’s effort to block renewal of the operating license of a reactor because of the Fukushima Daichi accident in Japan. The reactor, Pilgrim, resembles the reactors at Fukushima and is on the coast, at Plymouth, but in July the commission received a report from a task force that concluded that the Fukushima accident did not indicate any imminent risk to public health and safety from American reactors. Several states have tried unsuccessfully to block license extensions for reactors within their borders. Vermont could not stop re-licensing of a similar reactor, Vermont Yankee, owned by the same company as Pilgrim, Entergy, but the state is still trying to close it by denying a state permit.

headline.main: Massachusetts: Effort to Close Reactor Is Denied

lead_paragraph: DealBook explains some of the thinking behind the report that Facebook (no relation) may be planning an initial public offering in the spring to raise $10 billion, with a company valuation of $100 billion. In short, Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, writes, Facebook “just has too many shareholders.” When a United States company has 500 or more shareholders of record it must soon begin filing reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including audited financial information. Facebook is likely to reach 500 in April 2012, he writes, and most companies conclude that “if they are going to be subject to much of the regulation that comes with being public, they might as well just go ahead with an I.P.O. and get the full benefits of being public.”

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, I found myself flying back from Los Angeles after the unexpected death of my father-in-law, a longtime public defender who had a million times more “real” courtroom experience than a former “big law” type like myself could ever have (five years, two uncontested motions). He will be missed.

snippet: A four-year accord calls for union jobs on the 737 Max in Washington State, and if it is approved by members, the union said it would no longer contest a nonunion plant in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: After decades of bitter relations, Boeing and the machinists’ union vowed a new era of cooperation on Wednesday as they announced a far-reaching four-year contract extension that would raise wages, improve pensions and add thousands of new assembly jobs in Washington State to build an updated version of its 737 jet.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Look for changes in the proposed antipiracy legislation that has giants in the entertainment and technology industries squared off against each other, but nothing extensive enough to please all of the legislation’s opponents.
